overview.problemStatement:

Let $k\geq 2$ and $G$ be a graph with $n\geq k-1$ vertices and\[(k-1)(n-k+2)+\binom{k-2}{2}+1\]edges. Does there exist some $c_k>0$ such that $G$ must contain an induced subgraph on at most $(1-c_k)n$ vertices with minimum degree at least $k$?



The case $k=3$ was a problem of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal \cite{Er91}. The question for general $k$ was a conjecture of Erd\H{o}s, Faudree, Rousseau, and Schelp \cite{EFRS90}, who proved that such a subgraph exists with at most $n-c_k\sqrt{n}$ vertices. Mousset, Noever, and Skori\'{c} \cite{MNS17} improved this to\[n-c_k\frac{n}{\log n}.\]The full conjecture was proved by Sauermann \cite{Sa19}, who proved this with $c_k \gg 1/k^3$.




References


[EFRS90] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Faudree, R. J. and Rousseau, C. C. and
Schelp, R. H., Subgraphs of minimal degree {$k$}. Discrete Math. (1990), 53--58.

[Er91] Erd\"{o}s, P., Problems and results in combinatorial analysis and combinatorial number theory. Graph theory, combinatorics, and applications, Vol. 1 (Kalamazoo, MI, 1988) (1991), 397-406.

[MNS17] Mousset, Frank and Noever, Andreas and \v Skori\'c, Nemanja, Smaller subgraphs of minimum degree {$k$}. Electron. J. Combin. (2017), Paper No. 4.9, 8.

[Sa19] Sauermann, Lisa, A proof of a conjecture of Erd\H{o}s, Faudree, {R}ousseau
and {S}chelp on subgraphs of minimum degree {$k$}. J. Combin. Theory Ser. B (2019), 36--75.
